questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with episodes of brief involuntary muscular twitching that causes her to drop her toothbrush or teacup in the morning. Following investigations including an EEG, a diagnosis of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy was made. Which of the following is not a feature of it?
questions.solution:
In juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, EEG characteristically shows 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges.

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome):

  • It is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults ( 12-18 years).
  • They are benign generalized myoclonic seizures with a good prognosis.
  • They commonly affect the upper limbs more than the lower limbs and sometimes cause the dropping of objects.
  • Typically, it starts in early adolescence (12-18 years), with 1 or more of the following manifestations:
    • Myoclonic jerks in the morning (“shock-like” contraction of a muscle, that is often repeated), generalized tonic-clonic or clonic seizures upon awakening; and juvenile absences.
    • Sleep deprivation, alcohol (in older patients), and photic stimulation provoke seizures.
    • The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges.
  • The drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is valproate. Lamotrigine is also useful.
Disease Typical EEG features Drug of choice
Lennox–Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep Valproate 
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern) Ethosuximide
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike polyspike and slow-wave discharges Valproate 
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of RDS with surfactant is false?

choices.text: It is given in neonates with RDS who fail CPAP
It is given prophylactically to all neonates at < 31 weeks gestation.
It can be given as rescue treatment when RDS actually develops.
Repeated dosing is given every 6-12 hr for a total of 2 to 4 doses.

questions.solution:
Surfactant is given prophylactically to all neonates < 28 weeks, not 31 weeks. It is given irrespective of the presence or absence of RDS. The route of administration is intratracheal.

Surfactant is indicated in all infants with moderate to severe RDS. It is also given as a rescue treatment when CPAP fails.

questions.text: Shreya, a 2-year-old girl, presented with irritability for 2 days. On examination, macrocephaly, hypotonia and spasticity were present with a positive head transillumination test. She started walking independently at 18 months and became dry by day a month before her 2nd birthday. An MRI-brain revealed cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle and midline cerebellar hypoplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis explaining her obstructive hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
The features of hydrocephalus like irritability along with macrocephaly, hypotonia and spasticity indicate a likely diagnosis of Dandy-Walker syndrome. A positive transillumination test is present in this syndrome. The child has developmental delay especially in motor and cognitive milestones because normally children walk independently at 12-13 months and become dry by day around 18 months.

The Dandy-Walker malformation consists of a cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle in the posterior fossa and midline cerebellar hypoplasia. It results from a developmental failure of the roof of the fourth ventricle during embryogenesis. Most of the affected patients have hydrocephalus, agenesis of the posterior cerebellar vermis, and corpus callosum. Brisk tendon reflexes, spasticity, clonus, Babinski sign, cerebellar ataxia, and delayed motor and cognitive milestones are seen in this. Management is by shunting if hydrocephalus is present.

The image below shows a sagittal section of the magnetic resonance tomography scan of a patient with Dandy-Walker syndrome.

questions.text: Ayesha is a 9th standard girl who presented with a neck swelling, which began more than a year ago. Her mother says she is embarrassed about it and always covers her neck with a shawl when she goes to school. Her menstrual cycles have also become irregular as of late. Blood tests reveal slightly elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPO-Abs) and elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level in a child with a goitre is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis.

Chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease. Clinical presentation can include goitre, growth retardation, and other features of hypothyroidism. The thyroid is diffusely enlarged, firm, and non-tender.

TSH is moderately elevated and TPO-Abs and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies (anti-Tg Abs) can be detected.

The image given below shows goitre due to Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

questions.text: Gonads to testes differentiation is  most importantly determined by_________.
questions.solution:
Sex-determining region of the Y chromosome (SRY) is one of the most important regulators of sexual differentiation in males. In the absence of SRY, the bipotential gonad develops into the ovary.

Note:

Mullerian-inhibiting substance/Anti-Mullerian hormone also inhibits the development of the Mullerian duct, whereby female internal genitalia do not develop, thus promoting male genitalia formation.

questions.text: Cancer-'The emperor of all maladies spares no one'. Which of the following is the most common childhood malignancy?
questions.solution:
Leukemias are the most common childhood malignancies. Among these, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common, accounting for about 77% of childhood leukemias. 

Most commons in childhood malignancies:

  • Second most common malignancy in childhood: Brain tumor
  • Third most common malignancy in children: Lymphoma
  • Most common solid tumor in children: Brain tumor

questions.text: A 41-year-old entrepreneur is excited to start her family. She has been getting a lot of unsolicited advice about the complications of pregnancy in advanced maternal age. On enquiring about such pregnancies, the doctor advised the mother to get prenatal testing done. All are findings associated with the prenatal diagnosis for Down’s syndrome except _________

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect may be present

questions.solution:
Increased umbilical flow is not seen during the prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome, instead, the flow is decreased.

Reduced blood flow through the umbilical vessels and abnormal blood flow through ductus venosus (DV) in the first trimester are associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especially Down's syndrome. This decrease in blood flow causes IUGR in infants born with Down syndrome.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: Investigation of choice to diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency is estimation of ____________ levels.
questions.solution:
17-hydroxyprogesterone levels estimation is the investigation of choice to diagnose CAH due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency. It will be markedly elevated.

Other findings include:

  1. Elevated androstenedione and testosterone (in females).
  2. Low cortisol and aldosterone.
  3. Elevated ACTH levels.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her pediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient, normal physical findings except for a systolic murmur, and wide and fixed splitting of S2 are all in favor of a diagnosis of Atrial septal defect.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found.
The soft ejection systolic murmur is a flow murmur heard due to increased blood flow through the normal pulmonary valve. A delayed diastolic murmur can also be heard in the tricuspid area. As the right ventricle now receives more blood, the time required for its emptying is increased resulting in prolonged P2. Since the two atria are linked, inspiration does not produce any net pressure changes between them abolishing respiration-related changes in venous return hence causing fixed S2.

Causes of Wide and fixed splitting of S2 include,

  1. Atrial septal defect
  2. RBBB
  3. TAPVC

Other options:

TAPVC -  patients usually present with cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure around 4-10 weeks of age - this is when the fetal pulmonary vasculature regresses and there is increased pulmonary blood flow which results in early-onset cardiac failure. The physical findings are identical to ASD.

VSD - is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include a pansystolic murmur best heard in the left 4th parasternal area and a wide and variable split S2 which is usually masked by the pansystolic murmur.

PS - is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include an ejection systolic murmur and a thrill in the left second interface and a wide and variable split S2 because of delayed closure of P2.

questions.text: A pregnant female arrives at your hospital for her antenatal check-up. As an intern, you were required to draw her family pedigree chart while taking history. She has previously delivered full-term healthy dizygotic twins 5 years back. Which of the following symbol will you use to denote dizygotic twins in a pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Pedigree charts are graphical representations of a person's family tree and are useful for identifying the pattern of inheritance of genetic disorders. Thus, they are vital in the history-taking of patients, especially in pregnancy. Option B is the symbol denoting dizygotic twins in a pedigree chart.

Option A denotes monozygotic twins in the pedigree chart.
Option C denotes offsprings.
Option D denotes consanguineous marriage.

Related Pearl: Pedigree symbols

questions.text: A young girl presents to you with learning disabilities.  On examination, you notice a characteristic finding as shown in the picture below. Reports of her investigation scans mention horseshoe kidneys and streak gonads. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child shows characteristic webbed neck, learning disabilities, horseshoe kidneys, and streak gonads and is diagnosed with Turner’s syndrome.

Turner’s syndrome:

  • Karyotype, 45; XO, phenotypically females
  • Chromosomal abnormality XO is present in 60% of individuals, mosaic pattern in 40%
  • Intelligence remains normal

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome: (mnemonic: See A Baby CLOWN Here)

  • Short stature, Short fourth metacarpal, Sensorineural hearing loss, Shield chest
  • Amenorrhea (primary), infertility
  • Barr body absent
  • Cardiac defects, Cubitus valgus, Congenital lymphedema
  • L: Learning disabilities
  • Ovaries underdeveloped (streak ovaries), Gonadoblastoma (increased risk if Y chromosome material is present)
  • Webbed neck
  • Nipples widely spaced
  • Horseshoe kidneys

Note:

The most common cardiac defect in Turner's is bicuspid aortic valve > coarctation of aorta.

In Noonan's syndrome, the females are usually fertile and horseshoe kidneys are rarely seen.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented to the clinic for a missed vaccination. His routine anthropometric measurements were noted. He was found to be 90 cm tall with a lower segment of 45 cm. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options.

The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

High U/L ratio:

  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia
  • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism 

Low U/L ratio:

  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  • Vertebral anomalies

Arm span:

  • Length between the tips of the middle finger of the outstretched hands is the arm span.
  • It is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth; it equals height at 11 y and thereafter is slightly greater than height (usually<1 cm).

questions.text: A child developed dark coloured urine and flank pain 2 days after an upper respiratory tract infection. The physician suspects IgA nephropathy. What is the location of cellular injury in this condition?
questions.solution:
The location of cellular injury in IgA nephropathy (Berger nephropathy) is the deposition of IgA antibodies in the mesangial cell.

Mesangial cells are directly exposed to the circulation; therefore, they are affected in diseases characterized by the deposition of immune complexes.

Mesangial cell diseases:

  • IgA nephropathy
  • IgM nephropathy
  • Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Class II lupus nephritis
  • Diabetic nephropathy

Note: In IgA nephropathy gross hematuria often occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In contrast, a longer latency period of about 1-2 weeks is observed in acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treating with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Jaundice persisiting 3 weeks after birth is suggestive of pathological jaundice. Among the given options, Crigler Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia which responds to phenobarbital therapy.  

Dubin Johnson (option C) and Rotor (option A) syndromes lead to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in the enzyme UDP UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

The differences between Crigler-Najjar type 1 and type 2 are described in the table below:

Crigler Najjar Type 1   Crigler Najjar Type 2
Autosomal recessive   Autosomal recessive
UDPGT is absent   UDPGT is reduced
Severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia   Less severe
Pale stools   Normal-coloured stools
May proceed to kernicterus and does not respond to phenobarbitone   Does not proceed to kernicterus and is responsive to phenobarbitone

Related Pearl: Hereditary Hyperbilirubinemias

Disorder Inheritance Defects in bilirubin metabolism Clinical course

Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia

      

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I

AR

Absent UGT1A1 activity

Fatal in the neonatal period

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II

AR

Decreased UGT1A1 activity

Generally mild,

occasional kernicterus

Gilbert syndrome

AR (common)

AD (occasional)

Decreased UGT1A1 activity

Innocuous

Conjugated Hyperbilirubinemia

      

Dubin-Johnson syndrome

AR

Impaired biliary excretion of bilirubin glucuronides due to a mutation in canalicular multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2)

Innocuous with black pigmentation of liver

Rotor syndrome

AR

Decreased hepatic uptake and storage

Decreased biliary excretion

Innocuous

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

 Predominantly Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia  Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Excess production of bilirubin

  

Hemolytic anemias

Biliary tract obstruction

Resorption of blood from internal hemorrhage (e.g., alimentary tract bleeding, hematomas)

 Biliary tract diseases like primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis

Ineffective erythropoiesis (e.g., pernicious anemia, thalassemia)

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Reduced hepatic uptake

Rotor syndrome

Drug interference with membrane carrier systems

 Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis

Some cases of Gilbert syndrome

 Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis

Impaired bilirubin conjugation

  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn (decreased UGT1A1 activity, decreased excretion)

  

Breast milk jaundice (β-glucuronidases in milk)

  

Genetic deficiency of UGT1A1 activity (Crigler-Najjar syndrome types I and II)

  

Gilbert syndrome

  

Diffuse hepatocellular disease (e.g., viral or drug-induced hepatitis, cirrhosis)

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-month-old blue baby to your pediatric clinic for the first time. Neonatal records were not available but the mother says that the X-ray of the baby looked like that of a shoe. Which of the following wouldn't you expect in this baby?

choices.text: Large "a" waves in jugular venous pulse

questions.solution:
The given history of the shoe (boot) shaped heart in cyanotic baby is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot and cardiomegaly is not a part of TOF presentation. 

In the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), we see concentric right ventricular hypertrophy without cardiac enlargement. It is because of pulmonary stenosis (PS) and the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Any build-up of pressure in the right ventricle due to PS is released through VSD to the left ventricle.

Option A: P2 is of low intensity and soft because the right ventricular outflow obstruction results in reduced pulmonary artery pressure.

Option B: The aortic root usually appears large because it overrides (straddling) the VSD, allowing deoxygenated blood shunted from the right ventricle mixed with blood from the left ventricle to exit the heart.

Option D: The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.

questions.text: You are assisting on a left partial nephrectomy in a child with Wilms tumor. Intraoperatively, a small mass is noted on the right kidney as well. Frozen section reveals it to be a Wilms tumor. What is the stage of Wilm's tumor in this child?
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor with involvement of both kidneys is stage 5.

Children’s Oncology Group (COG) Staging System

Stage I

Tumor confined to the kidney and completely resected with negative lymph nodes.

Stage II

Tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely resected with negative margins and lymph nodes.

Stage III

Residual tumor present following surgery confined to the abdomen, including gross or microscopic tumor.

Stage IV

Hematogenous metastases (lung, liver, bone, brain, etc.)

or lymph node metastases outside the abdominopelvic region

Stage V

Metastasis to opposite kidney (bilateral renal involvement)

questions.text: The parents of a neonate diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia come with queries about the disease. They have been told that it's an inherited condition and ask you how is it possible for the baby to be affected when neither of the parents are. What is the mode of inheritance of the disease?
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia / adrenogenital syndrome follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

Depending on the enzyme that is deficient, patients will have :

  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia) or excess (hypernatremia, hypokalemia)
  • Incomplete virilization or precocious puberty in males
  • Virilization or sexual infantilism in females

questions.text: An unbooked primigravida, with no antenatal records, delivers a 2.5kg male baby by normal delivery. While ascertaining the maturity of the child, which of the following would be against a diagnosis of prematurity?
questions.solution:
Thick cartilage with a stiff ear in a newborn is a sign of maturity (not prematurity).

Score Ear
0 Pinna flat and stays folded; no recoil
1 Slightly curved pinna; soft; slow recoil
2 Well-curved pinna; soft but ready recoil
3 Formed & firm, instant recoil
4 Thick cartilage, ear stiff

No creases on the sole, insignificant breast nodule, and empty scrotum are all physical signs of prematurity in a newborn.

Note:

Abundant lanugo hair is not discriminatory evidence of prematurity. This is because neonates of diabetic mothers born as a term or even post-term have abundant lanugo hair, especially over the pinna and upper back.

questions.text: Reena, a 34-year-old lady with gestation diabetes mellitus delivers an LGA baby at 37 weeks. What would the birth weight of this child be?
questions.solution:
Infants with birth weight greater than the 90th percentile for their gestational age are called large for gestational age (LGA) babies.

Maternal diabetes and obesity are predisposing factors for LGA babies. They have a higher incidence of: 

  • Birth injuries:  
    • Brachial plexus injury
    • Phrenic nerve injury
    • Cephalohematomas
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Polycythemia
  • Congenital heart disease

questions.text: NADA’s criteria is used in

choices.text: Assessment of child for the presence of malnutition
Assessment of child for the presence of dehydration
Assessment of child for the presence of heart disease
Assessment of child for the presence of mental retardation

questions.solution:
• NADA’s criteria is used to assess the presence of heart disease in children.
  • Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.
Major criteria Minor criteria
Systolic murmur grade 3 or more Systolic murmur grade 1 or 2
Diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound
Cyanosis Abnormal EKG
Congestive cardiac failure Abnormal X-ray
  Abnormal BP

questions.text: A 9-day-old infant has elevated TSH level and low T4 level on newborn screening. If this condition is left untreated, which of the following is most likely to be seen in this infant in the first few months of life?
questions.solution:
Elevated TSH levels and low T4 levels in a 9-day-old infant are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia is an early sign of congenital hypothyroidism. It is due to delayed maturation of the hepatic glucuronide conjugation system.

Hyperreflexia, hyperirritability and diarrhoea are seen in hyperthyroidism; not hypothyroidism.

Note:

Kocher–Debré–Sémélaigne syndrome: The muscles are usually hypotonic in congenital hypothyroidism. Rarely, hypothyroidism in infancy can be characterized by generalized muscular pseudohypertrophy, myxoedema, short stature and cretinism. Affected older children can have an athletic appearance. Boys are more prone to the development of the syndrome.

questions.text: An incessantly crying 5-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her father. You observe that she needs support to walk and her trunk is not symmetrically aligned. There is a history of recurrent fractures in her limbs. She also has blood-stained vaginal discharge from a few days. On examination, the girl appears as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty(vaginal discharge), bony lesions (polyostotic fibrous dysplasia), and cafe au lait spots, as shown in the picture, are features of McCune–Albright syndrome. There is pain due to the multiple bony lesions and repeated fractures may result in incessant crying in the children and may require regular visits to the orthopaedics department. 

McCune–Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by a mutation of GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues.

Fibrous dysplasia of multiple bones (polyostotic) represents a major cause of morbidity in this syndrome. The base of the skull and the proximal femurs are most commonly involved, but any bone can be affected. A CT scan is usually recommended even in absence of deformities. The prognosis is favourable for longevity, but deformities, repeated fractures, pain, and occasional cranial nerve compression may result from the bony lesions.

Cardinal features:

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Cafe au lait macules
  • Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty
  • Predominantly affects girls

questions.text: Cheilitis is caused by _____.
questions.solution:
Cheilitis is dryness of the lips followed by scaling and cracking, accompanied by a burning sensation. It is common in children. It is caused by

  • Frequent lip licking
  • Vitamin B2, B6, B12 deficiency
  • Weakened immune system
  • Sensitivity to contact substances
  • Bacterial or fungal infections

Treatment: Frequent application of petroleum jelly and antibacterial/antifungal agents.

questions.text: Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by ______.
questions.solution:
Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by the umbilical vein.

The umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus into the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in the fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava.

The umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta for oxygenation. 

 

Note:

In the umbilical cord, there are a pair of umbilical arteries and a single umbilical vein.

Mnemonic: AVA- artery –vein- artery(2 arteries and a single vein).

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: An ECG finding of right ventricular enlargement in a 2-year-old child is most consistent with which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
In atrial septal defect (ASD), there is a left-to-right shunt, resulting in increased blood flow through the right side of the heart, which leads to enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle and dilation of the pulmonary artery, the left atrium may also be enlarged, but the left ventricle and aorta are normal in size.

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): There is shunting of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary trunk, which goes into the lungs and then again to the LA and LV. If the ductus is large, left ventricular or biventricular hypertrophy is present.

In ventricular septal defect (VSD), there is shunting of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle, but most of the blood is shunted directly to the inflow tract of the pulmonary trunk, so, there is no significant right ventricular hypertrophy. In VSD, the pulmonary artery left atrium, and left ventricle are enlarged.

In Tricuspid atresia, there is right to left shunting of blood through an ASD as the tricuspid valve is dysfunctional due to which the entire systemic venous return enters the left side of the heart using the foramen ovale or through an ASD, and hence, there is left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text:
A 20-month-old child diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is receiving treatment in your clinic. Given below are five statements regarding the treatment. Pick out the incorrect statements.
  1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started from day 1 of admission.
  2. The stabilization phase would ideally include the first seven days of treatment.
  3. Vitamin A is given daily to overcome micronutrient deficiency.
  4. F-75 feeds can be initiated in split portions.
  5. Promote skin to skin contact with mother to avoid hypothermia.
questions.solution:
Vitamin A is not given daily in the treatment of SAM. It is given on day 1, day 2 and day 14.

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.

Mnemonic: SHIELDED

  • Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia) 
  • Hypothermia
  • Infection
  • ELectrolyte imbalance
  • DEhydration
  • Deficiency of nutrients

Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks.

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL.  After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is made which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text:
Which of the following mothers can initiate breastfeeding?
  1. A mother with an active infection of herpes on both her breasts.
  2. A mother with positive serology for hepatitis B infection.
  3. A mother with active tuberculosis.
  4. A mother who is on treatment with chemotherapeutic agents for leukaemia.
  5. A mother with a history of chronic smoking.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 2 and 5 only. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated if the mother has hepatitis B infection or if she is a chronic smoker.

Infants born to an HbsAg positive mother routinely receive hepatitis B immunoglobulin and hepatitis B vaccine. So, a delay in the initiation of breastfeeding is not required.

Contraindications of breastfeeding:

Do not Breastfeed

Do not give expressed breastmilk

Infant factors:

  • Classic galactosemia

Maternal factors:

  • Human T-cell lymphocyte virus (HTLV) infection
  • Ebola virus infection
  • PCP/cocaine abuse

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Do not give expressed breastmilk  (Temporarily)

Maternal factors:

  • Brucellosis
  • undergoing diagnostic imaging with radiopharmaceuticals
  • Active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection with lesions on the breasts

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Can give expressed breastmilk

Maternal factors:

  • Untreated, active Tuberculosis
  • Active Varicella infection

Alcohol consumption and smoking are NOT contraindications of breastfeeding. However, smoking and alcohol consumption should be discouraged.

Note: In a mother with untreated, active tuberculosis:

  • Temporarily withhold breastfeeding but can feed with expressed breastmilk
  • Resume breastfeeding once she has been adequately treated for 2 weeks and is no longer contagious.

WHO recommendations on breastfeeding in HIV infection:

  • Start mothers on antiretroviral therapy (ART)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months
  • Continue breastfeeding for at least 12 months, with the addition of complementary feeds.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought by his mother with new-onset nocturnal bedwetting. She also reported, he has been drinking more water for the last 3-4 months. 24-hour urine volume was 4 liters and the urine osmolality was low. ADH assays recorded a value was 0.7 pg/mL. T1 weighted MRI brain indicated an absence of a pituitary bright spot. What is the treatment of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. The treatment of choice is desmopressin. It is a vasopressin analog (V2 receptor agonist). It can be administered intranasally, or subcutaneously. 

Option A: Leuprolide is a GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) analog used in the treatment of prostate cancer, breast cancer, and endometriosis.

Option B: Thiazides paradoxically exert an antidiuretic effect in DI but are not the drug of choice. They are generally used in nephrogenic DI.

Option D: Terlipressin is a long-acting analog on vasopressin that acts on V1 receptors of vascular smooth muscle. It is used as a vasopressor in shock and acute variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A mother brought her 10-month-old baby to the hospital with sudden onset vomiting. She has also been noticing an alarming increase in the head size of the baby. On examination, significant macrocephaly is seen. MRI reveals a supratentorial tumor. Which of the following tumors is the most likely cause of this child's presentation?
questions.solution:
Choroid plexus carcinoma is a pediatric supratentorial tumor presenting with macrocephaly and focal neurologic deficits.

Choroid plexus tumors are the most common CNS tumors in children aged less than 1 year. These tumors are intraventricular epithelial neoplasms arising from the choroid plexus. 

Children present with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), whereas infants may present with macrocephaly and focal neurologic deficits.

Medulloblastoma, pilocytic astrocytoma, and ependymoma, are all predominantly infratentorial tumors.

The age-related differences in the primary location of the tumor are given below:

Age Predominant Site Examples
< 1 year Supratentorial Choroid plexus tumor and teratoma
1 - 10 years Infratentorial Juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma and medulloblastoma
> 10 years Supratentorial Diffuse astrocytoma

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is an FDA approved indication for GH treatment to promote growth?
questions.solution:
• Turner’s syndrome (45XO) is characterized by short stature and ovarian dysgenesis (B/L streak ovaries). The short stature in Turner’s will improve with growth hormone administration.
  • Klinefelter’s syndrome (47XXY) is characterized by tall stature, eunuchoid appearance, sterility and gynaecomastia. Due to tall stature, growth hormone therapy is unnecessary.
  • Laron dwarfism is due to a mutation in GH receptor leading to end organ resistance to GH. The circulating levels of GH are already high, therefore GH therapy is unnecessary. The condition may improve with administration of human recombinant IGF-1.
  • Maternal deprivation dwarfism: in this condition, dwarfism is due to psychosocial causes such as emotional deprivation and neglect. Hence, GH therapy is not required.

GCTS IN Prader -Willi Syndrome

8 FDA approved indications for GH treatment

GH deficiency, Turner syndrome, chronic renal failure before transplantation, idiopathic short stature, small-for-gestational
age short stature, Prader-Willi syndrome, SHOX gene abnormality,
and Noonan syndrome

Recombinant Growth hormone is used for treatment.

questions.text: You are asked to review an article titled, 'Childhood cancers- a menace'. Which of the following statements is wrong and needs to be edited out?

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common type of leukemia in children with Down syndrome.
The most common intra-abdominal malignancy is Wilm’s tumor.
The most common extracranial solid malignancy is neuroblastoma.
The most common brain tumors in children are infratentorial.

questions.solution:
The most common intraabdominal malignancy in children is neuroblastoma. 

  • The most common leukemias seen in Down’s syndrome: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) > acute myeloid leukemia (AML)
  • The most common site of a brain tumor in children: Infratentorium
  • The most common extra-cranial solid neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma
  • The most common intra-abdominal neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma
  • The most common primary neoplasm of renal tissue in children: Wilm’s tumor

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of atrial septal defect?
questions.solution:
Ostium secundum ASD (labelled as 3) is the most common type of atrial septal defect (ASD), located at the mid-inter-atrial septum, in the region of the fossa ovalis.

ASD is characterized by an abnormal opening in the atrial septum allowing communication between the right and left atria. There are four types based on their location within the septum:

  • Secundum ASD - most common, usually an isolated abnormality
  • Primum ASD - associated with abnormal mitral valve leaflet (partial AV septal defect)
  • Sinus venous - is located at the junction of the superior vena cava and right atrium. Associated with anomalous right pulmonary venous return to the SVC or RA
  • Coronary sinus type ASD - also called unroofed coronary sinus

Ostium primum ASD: is located at lower atrial septum

Endocardial cushion defect/An AV septal defect/ AV canal defect consists of contiguous atrial and VSDs with markedly abnormal AV valves. The lesion is common in children with Down syndrome.

Congenital conditions associated with ASD include:

  • Down's syndrome - usually an ostium primum defect
  • Holt-Oram syndrome - autosomal dominant disorder with upper limb bony defects and cardiac septal defects, commonly secundum ASD
  • Ellis-van Creveld syndrome - chondroectodermal dysplasia associated with postaxial polydactyly and ASD
  • Lutembacher syndrome - combined ASD and mitral stenosis due to rheumatic valvulitis
  • Mitral valve prolapse

Related Pearl: Locations of Congenital Heart Disease

questions.text: Anwesha, an orator preparing for her international debate finale presents to your clinic with lesions on her lower lip as shown below. She is concerned as these lesions are painful, recurrent and hamper the flow of her speech. Which of the following points about this condition is incorrect?

choices.text: They are seen in Gluten-sensitive enteropathy

questions.solution:
The lesions given in the above image are aphthous ulcers, and they are not contagious. All the other points are true. 

Aphthous ulcers are painful, recurrent, and non-contagious oral lesions. They are well-circumscribed, ulcerative lesions with a white necrotic base surrounded by a red halo. They heal in 10–14 days without scarring. Their aetiology is unclear but the following factors have been implicated:

    1. Allergic or immunologic reactions
    2. Emotional stress
    3. Genetics
    4. Injury to soft tissues in the mouth
    5. Inflammatory bowel disease
    6. Gluten-sensitive enteropathy
    7. Behcet disease
    8. Sweet syndrome
    9. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
    10. Cyclical neutropenia

Treatment generally includes local anaesthetic to relieve pain and B-complex supplementation to enhance healing.

questions.text: A male is said to have delayed puberty if it is not attained by:
questions.solution:
• Lack of pubertal changes in boys by the age of 14 years is suggestive of delayed puberty.
  • Delayed puberty is more common in boys than girls.
  • Constitutional delay in growth and puberty is the commonest cause of delayed puberty in boys.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother who is concerned about her significant increase in height compared to her classmates in the last 2 years. On examination, the girl shows breast development corresponding to B2 Tanner stage. What is the most common brain lesion causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Hypothalamic hamartoma, a neuronal migration defect, is the most common cause of organic central precocious puberty. The onset of breast development before the age of 8 years in females and onset of testicular development (>4 mL) before the age of 9 years in males is suggestive of central precocious puberty. 

It is a congenital malformation that consists of ectopically located neural tissue characterised by-

  • Early-onset of puberty
  • Seizures associated with unnatural crying or laughing episodes are known as gelastic seizures.

Tuberculous meningitis, tuberous sclerosis, and astrocytomas can also cause central precocious puberty.

questions.text: The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess ________
questions.solution:
The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • It can be used to calculate gestational age from 20 to 44 weeks.
  • The Ballard scoring is accurate to +/- 2 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as plumboporphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning?
questions.solution:
δ-Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ALAD) is also called plumboporphyria/Doss porphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning, although it is not related to lead exposure.

ALAD catalyzes the condensation of 2 molecules of ALA to form the pyrrole porphobilinogen (PBG). The enzyme is subject to inhibition by lead because ALAD is the principal lead-binding protein in erythrocytes, and lead can displace the zinc atoms of the enzyme, thus inhibiting it. Therefore, both lead poisoning and ALAD porphyria produce similar signs and symptoms. Symptoms resemble those of other acute porphyrias, including acute attacks of abdominal pain and neuropathy.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
Porphyria type
Deficient  enzyme
Lab findings
  
Symptoms
X-linked dominant protoporphyria
(XLDPP)
δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2
(ALAS - 2)
 Decreased RBC count and hemoglobin
Cutaneous photosensitivity
Photosensitivity
Aminolevulinate dehydratase deficiency porphyria
(ALADP)
δ-aminolevulinate dehydratase
(ALAD)
 Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III  Neurovisceral symptoms
Abdominal pain, neuropathy
Acute intermittent porphyria
(AIP)
Hydroxymethylbilane synthase
(Uroporphyrin I synthase)
 Increased urinary ALA and PBG  Neurovisceral symptoms 
Periodic abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, psychiatric symptoms, tachycardia
Congenital Erythropoietic porphyria
(CEP)
Uroporphyrinogen III synthase
(UROS)
 Increased urinary, fecal and red cell uroporphyrin I Cutaneous photosensitivity
Severe photosensitivity with erythema, swelling and blistering, hemolytic anemia, splenomegaly
Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT)
Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase
(UROD)

Cutaneous photosensitivity
Photosensitivity with vesicles and bullae
Hereditary coproporphyria
(HCP)
Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
(CPOX)

Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, abdominal colic
Variegate porphyria
(VP)
Protoporphyrinogen oxidase
(PPOX)
 Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal protoporphyrin IX Both
Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, developmental delay
Erythropoietic protoporphyria
(EPP)
Ferrochelatase
(FECH)
 Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX  Cutaneous photosensitivity
Non-blistering Photosensitivity with skin lesions
 
Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatrician for vaccination. The child is able to speak in	2-3 word sentences and is able to make a tower of 6 cubes. What is the expected weight of the child, if his development is normal and birth weight was 3 Kgs?
questions.solution:
The child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes and speaks in 2-3 word sentences which indicates the child is of 2 years of age. Birth weight quadruples by the age of 2 years. Hence the child's weight should be 3 kgs x 4= 12 Kgs.

Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life and regain it by their 2nd week.

Related Pearl: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

  • 0-3 months ~ 30 grams/day
  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day
  • 6-12months ~ 12-15 grams/day

Note : Infant weight approximately Doubles at 4-5 months , Triples by 1year and is 4 times by 2 years of age.

Weight gained with respect to birth weight

Age Weight
5 months 2 × birth weight
1 year 3 × birth weight
2 years 4 × birth weight
3 years 5 × birth weight

Formulae for calculating the weight in children

Age Formula
3-12 months
Weight =[age (months) + 9]
2
1-6 years Weight = [2×age (years)] + 8
7-12 years
Weight = [7×age (years) - 5]
2

Height with respect to age

Age Height
At birth 50 cm
6 months 65 cm
1 year 75 cm
2 years 90 cm
4 years 100 cm

 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: Immediately following vaginal delivery, a baby is noted to have a diffuse ecchymotic swelling on the scalp. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is caput succedaneum.

Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp, involving the presenting part in a vertex delivery. It may extend across the midline and crosses suture lines.

Option A: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.

Option C: Subgaleal hemorrhages occur with the rupture of emissary veins, which connect the dural sinuses with the superficial veins of the scalp. Blood accumulates between the epicranial aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum and resolves over 2-3 weeks. Often associated with vacuum-assisted delivery.

Option D: Epidural hemorrhages, usually traumatic in origin, are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or occur as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: The total fetal cardiac output at term is estimated to be_________ per minute.
questions.solution:
The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

Approximately 65% of descending aortic blood flow returns to the placenta, and hence, only the remaining 35% perfuses the fetal organs and tissues.

The clinical relevance of this 65% blood flow being directed to the placenta comes in the context of delayed cord clamping vs early cord clamping after delivery. Delayed cord clamping entails the umbilical cord is clamped more than one minute after the birth or when cord pulsation has ceased. This delayed clamping allows the blood flow between the placenta and neonate to continue and helps improve the iron status in the infant.

Recently, umbilical cord milking is being evaluated for use as an improved alternative to delayed cord clamping. Here the umbilical cord is grasped and blood is pushed towards the infant several times so as to re infuse blood into the preterm neonate.

questions.text: An anxious mother has brought a 4-month-old baby with complaints that the baby is not feeding well and is excessively sleepy all the time. Clinical examination reveals jaundice and hypotonia. His picture is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows a child with a protuberant abdomen, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, and edematous facies. Also, the infant is sluggish, has jaundice, feeding difficulties, and hypotonia, all of which suggests a diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia- early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation- usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular- slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory- macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Haematological- macrocytic anaemia refractory to treatment with haematinics
  • Nervous system- hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence

questions.text: You are demonstrating findings in a pediatric OSCE examination on a 4-day old neonate. On turning the baby's head to the left, you obtain the finding as shown below. At what age does this reflex normally disappear?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) disappears by 6 months postnatally.

The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated and flexion of the contralateral arm).

An obligatory tonic neck response, in which the infant becomes “stuck” in the fencing posture, is always abnormal and implies a CNS disorder.

Note: According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

 
Reflex
Onset
Fully developed 
Duration
Palmar grasp
28 weeks of gestation
32 weeks of gestation
2-3 months postnatal
Rooting
32 weeks of gestation
36 weeks of gestation
Less prominent after 1 month postnatal
Moro
28-32 weeks of gestation
37 weeks of gestation
5-6 months postnatal
Tonic neck
35 weeks of gestation
1 month postnatal
3-4 months postnatal
Parachute
7-8 months postnatal
10-11 months postnatal
Remains throughout life

 

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: An anxious new mother feeding her child with expressed breastmilk (EBM) feels that the consistency and colour of her milk have changed recently. She adds that when she expresses breastmilk, the colour and consistency of the first portion and the ending portion is completely different and that she is worried about the same.  Which statement is not true about different breast milk?

choices.text: Mature milk is thicker with all the essential nutrients for growth
Foremilk is watery and is rich in proteins and sugar
Hindmilk is richer in fat and provides more energy

questions.solution:
Mature milk is thinner (not thicker) with all essential nutrients for growth.

Various transitional forms of breastmilk:

Colostrum

  • In the initial 3 to 4 days
  • Small quantity, thick, and yellow in colour
  • A large number of antibodies, immune component cells; and vitamins A, D, E, and K.

Transitional milk

  • Secreted after 3 to 4 days until 2 weeks
  • Immunoglobulin and protein content decreases, while the fat and sugar content increases.

Mature milk

  • Follows transitional milk.
  • Thinner and more watery.
  • Contains all the nutrients essential for the optimal growth of the baby. 

Foremilk

  • Secreted at the start of the feed
  • Watery and rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water that quenches the baby’s thirst.

Hindmilk 

  • Comes towards the end of the feed
  • Provides more energy and a sense of satiety and it is richer in fat.

Preterm milk 

  • Milk of mother who delivers before 37 weeks.
  • Contains more proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobins, and calories as per the requirement of the preterm infant.

The given image shows watery foremilk and hindmilk which is rich in fat.

questions.text: A child in your unit is receiving treatment for chronic diarrhea. His diet history is remarkable for a high phytate-rich diet. His labs reveal low serum zinc. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of chronic zinc deficiency. Zinc deficiency affects both cell-mediated and humoral immunity. The cell-mediated immunity is impaired predominantly, as zinc is essential for T-cell division, maturation, and differentiation. 

In a child with a phytate-rich diet, a chronic deficiency of zinc and iron usually co-exist. Isolated chronic zinc deficiency can be seen in the setting of a child suffering from chronic diarrhoea, repeated pneumonia or chest infections, and congenital malabsorption disorders.

Chronic zinc deficiency manifests as:

  1. Dwarfism
  2. Hypogonadism
  3. Dermatitis of extremities and around orifices
  4. T-cell immunodeficiency
  5. Diarrhoea 

The features of acute zinc deficiency include:

  1. Decreased growth
  2. Poor wound healing 
  3. Diarrhea

questions.text: All of the following are considered normal in a newborn except

choices.text: Tuft of hair over LS spine

questions.solution:
A tuft of hair over the lumbosacral spine is not a normal finding in newborns. It suggests an underlying abnormality such as an occult spina bifida, a sinus tract, or a tumor.

Normal skin findings in a newborn:

  • Erythema toxicum – small white papules on an erythematous base, seen 1-3 days after birth. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.
  • Pustular melanosis – Seen predominantly in black neonates, they contain neutrophils and are present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption. Lasts for 2-3 days.
  • Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. They tend to disappear within the first year.

questions.text: You are reading an article titled, ' Dark age vampires or our patients', which describes an 18-year-old man who has had an intolerance to sunshine since the age of 6. When playing cricket he suffered intense burning, redness, swelling, and crusting of knees unprotected by shorts, with similar changes on cheeks and bridge of the nose. His labs showed elevated concentrations of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies can explain this boy's condition?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of cutaneous photosensitivity beginning in childhood and a substantially elevated concentration of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin supports a diagnosis of erythropoietic protoporphyria. The enzyme deficient in erythropoietic protoporphyria is ferrochelatase (FECH).

Symptoms consist of acute pain and itching often occurring within minutes of sunlight exposure and followed by redness and swelling with continued exposure. Swelling may resemble angioneurotic edema and solar urticaria. Symptoms are usually worse in the spring and summer. Chronic changes may include lichenification, leathery pseudovesicles, labial grooving, and nail changes, but changes in pigmentation and pronounced scarring are unusual.

Life-threatening protoporphyric hepatopathy is characterized by greater increases in erythrocyte and plasma protoporphyrin levels, increased photosensitivity, and either chronically abnormal liver function tests or rapidly progressive hepatic failure.

Afamelanotide, a synthetic analogue of the alpha-melanocyte-stimulating hormone is recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of erythropoietic protoporphyria. The drug acts by increasing sunlight tolerance.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
Porphyria type
Deficient  enzyme
Lab findings
  
Symptoms
X-linked dominant protoporphyria
(XLDPP)
δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2
(ALAS - 2)
 Decreased RBC count and hemoglobin
Cutaneous photosensitivity
Photosensitivity
Aminolevulinate dehydratase deficiency porphyria
(ALADP)
δ-aminolevulinate dehydratase
(ALAD)
 Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III  Neurovisceral symptoms
Abdominal pain, neuropathy
Acute intermittent porphyria
(AIP)
Hydroxymethylbilane synthase
(Uroporphyrin I synthase)

Periodic abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, psychiatric symptoms, tachycardia
Congenital Erythropoietic porphyria
(CEP)
Uroporphyrinogen III synthase
(UROS)
 Increased urinary, fecal and red cell uroporphyrin I Cutaneous photosensitivity
Severe photosensitivity with erythema, swelling and blistering, hemolytic anemia, splenomegaly
Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT)
Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase
(UROD)

Cutaneous photosensitivity
Photosensitivity with vesicles and bullae
Hereditary coproporphyria
(HCP)

(CPOX)
 Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal coproporphyrin III Both
Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, abdominal colic
Variegate porphyria
(VP)
Protoporphyrinogen oxidase
(PPOX)

Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, developmental delay
Erythropoietic protoporphyria
(EPP)

(FECH)

Non-blistering Photosensitivity with skin lesions
 
Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl, a known case of celiac disease, presented to the pediatric endocrine clinic with a history of neck swelling, tremor, and weight loss. On evaluation, she was found to have Graves’ disease. Other conditions that need to be screened in this patient include all of the following except __________.
questions.solution:
Type 2 Diabetes mellitus is not associated with Grave's disease.

Conditions associated with Grave's disease (autoimmune diseases): 

  • Diabetes mellitus type 1
  • Pernicious anaemia
  • Celiac disease
  • Vitiligo
  • Addison disease
  • Alopecia areata
  • Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: What is the shape of caecum in the newborn
questions.solution:
• The shape of caecum in an infant is conical with appendix at the base of the cone
  • Thereafter caecum descends and assumes its round shape

questions.text: The newborn cardiac output is
questions.solution:
The newborn cardiac output is 350ml/kg/min.

Age Cardiac output(ml/kg/min)
Fetus 450
Newborn 350
1-2 months of life 150
Adult 75

questions.text:
A child with CAH having cortisol deficiency is treated with glucocorticoids. How should the dose of glucocorticoids be altered during an inter-current infection?

CAH - Congenital Adrenal hyperplasia

choices.text: Dose should be tapered and stopped
Dose should be doubled or tripled
Glucocorticoids should be withdrawn until the infection resolves

questions.solution:
Cortisol deficiency in CAH is treated with glucocorticoids.

Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as an infection or surgery. This is because, during periods of stress, the requirement for cortisol is higher.
